data.title: Prize Winners, Literary Prizes, Pulitzer, National Book Award
data.meta_description: A list of award winners, the years the awards were won, and the books for which they won
data.text:
Prize Winners

Some collectors center their collecting on categories of major prize winners: the Booker, Caldecott, Edgar, Hugo, National Book, Nebula, Newbery, PEN/Faulkner, Pulitzer prizes, or on lists of high spots compiled by knowledgeable authors, such as the Connolly 100, Queen's Quorom, and on and on. The following are some of these award winners, the years the awards were won, and the books for which they won. A more comprehensive list of literary awards, in some cases with the runners-up or short-listed authors, was published by Charlene Coffield in 1998. The title is Notable Literary Awards for Fiction and is available from her at 1401 Emerald Circel, Southlake, TX 76092. In addition, the American Library Association Web site (www.ala.org) has links to many of the award sites. Also see http://www.bookwire.com.

Note that we have listed the books in the year of their award, although in most cases the prizes were awarded the year following their publication (i.e., the 1992 Hugo Award is for the Best Novel Published in 1991).

You can scroll down to view the lists of awards, or click on a link below to "jump" to a particular awards list.

The [Man] Booker Prize

The Man Booker Prize

Formerly the Booker Prize, the Man Booker is awarded annually for the best literature in the British Commonwealth of Nations. To visit their site go to www.themanbookerprize.com

The Caldecott Medal

The Caldecott Medal is awarded annually by the Association for Library Service to Children (a division of the American Library Association) to the artist of the most distinguished picture book for children. The award was named in honor of Randolph Caldecott, a nineteenth-century illustrator whose work is still delighting children. To visit their site go to www.ala.org

The Edgar

The Edgar is an annual award named in honor of Edgar Allan Poe, presented by the Mystery Writers of America. To visit their site go to www.mysterywriters.org

The Hugo Award for Science Fiction Achievement

The Hugo was named in honor of Hugo Gernsback, the founder of the first professional science fiction magazine. The winner is chosen by a mail vote by the attending and supporting members of each World Science Fiction Convention. To visit their site go to http://www.thehugoawards.org

The Newbery Medal

The Newbery is awarded annually by the Association for Library Service to Children (a division of the American Library Association) to the author of the most distinguished contribution to American literature for children. Named for eighteenth-century British bookseller John Newbery. To visit their site go to www.ala.org

PEN/Faulkner Award

PEN/Faulkner was founded in 1980 by writers to honor their peers, and is now the largest juried award for fiction in the United States. It is named in honor of William Faulkner, who used his Nobel Prize funds to create an award for young writers. To visit their site go to www.penfaulkner.org

Pulitzer Prize Winners for Fiction

Joseph Pulitzer, a publisher of the New York Globe, established the Pulitzer Prize through an endowment to Columbia University. The prizes are awarded annually. The Fiction Award is given for fiction in book form by an American author, preferably dealing with American life. To visit their site go to www.pulitzer.org

Pulitzer Prize Winners for History

The Pulitzer Prize for History is for a distinguished and appropriately documented book on the history of the United States. To visit their site go to www.pulitzer.org
